title: Grocery Delivery for Elderly Care Centers
content:

✓ Arrive within each center’s time window (early arrivals wait).  
✓ End routes at the last center, as drivers assist with unloading.  
The goal is to minimize total travel distance while ensuring timely deliveries.

Each scenario emphasizes:  
- **Capacity**: Vehicle load limits for specialized goods (art crates, medical supplies, etc.)  
- **Open Routes**: Vehicles conclude operations at final destinations (e.g., disaster sites, galleries)  
- **Time Windows**: Strict service intervals (medical appointments, flight schedules, etc.)  

Let me know if you'd like further refinements!

title: Just-in-Time Fashion Sample Delivery for Buyers
content: A fashion house delivers sample collections to luxury buyers' offices (<loc_customer>) from its design studio (<loc_depot>). Each courier van (capacity = <capacity> garment bags) must arrive during buyers' pre-booked viewing appointments (<time_windows>). Deliveries require <service_time> minutes for inspection sign-off. Couriers finish routes at the last appointment location. With high-value items and strict scheduling constraints, the goal is to minimize travel distance while meeting all time windows and preventing garment overloading in vehicles.

title: Mobile EV Charging for Urban Ride-Sharing Fleets
content: A charging service provider must deploy mobile charging units to replenish electric ride-sharing vehicles (e.g., Uber/Lyft) across a city. Each ride-sharing vehicle (<loc_customer>) has a specific charging time window (<time_windows>) based on driver availability and a battery capacity demand (<demand>). Charging trucks (<capacity>) start from a central depot (<loc_depot>) but do not return after their last service. The goal is to minimize total travel distance while ensuring no truck exceeds its battery supply capacity and all vehicles are serviced within their operational time slots.

title: Just-in-Time Aircraft Catering Delivery
content: An airline catering company must deliver meals to multiple aircraft (<loc_customer>) at an airport during tight turnaround windows (<time_windows>). Each flight requires a unique meal quantity (<demand>), and delivery trucks (<capacity>) start from the kitchen (<loc_depot>). Trucks cannot return to the depot after their final delivery due to airport traffic constraints (open routes). The objective is to optimize routes to meet all flight schedules without overloading trucks or missing time windows.

title: Pop-Up COVID-19 Booster Shot Clinics
content: A health agency operates mobile vaccination teams that visit temporary clinics (<loc_customer>) in underserved neighborhoods. Each clinic has a strict operating window (<time_windows>) and vaccine demand (<demand>). Vans (<capacity>) depart from a central cold storage depot (<loc_depot>) but remain at the final clinic to avoid wasted trips. The challenge is to maximize coverage while ensuring vaccine cold chain capacity limits and clinic time constraints are met.

title: Luxury Watch Showroom Appointments
content: A high-end watch brand hosts pop-up showrooms at luxury hotels (<loc_customer>). Each hotel has exclusive appointment slots (<time_windows>) and requires a specific number of demo watches (<demand>). Security vans (<capacity>) transport watches from a vault (<loc_depot>) but park overnight at the final location due to security protocols. Routes must minimize travel time while adhering to strict delivery windows and vehicle weight limits for valuable cargo.

title: Temporary Urban Beehive Pollination Services
content: An agricultural cooperative deploys portable beehives to urban farms (<loc_customer>) during precise flowering periods (<time_windows>). Each farm needs a customized number of hives (<demand>). Transport trucks (<capacity>) start from an apiary (<loc_depot>) but end routes at the last farm to avoid disturbing bees with unnecessary movement. The solution must optimize hive distribution while respecting both truck capacity and narrow biological time windows for pollination.

title: Mobile EV Charging for Urban Ride-Sharing Fleets
content: A charging service provider must deploy mobile charging units to replenish electric ride-sharing vehicles across a city. Each EV has a specific location (<loc_customer>), battery capacity (<demand> kWh), and a narrow charging window (<time_windows>) based on driver shifts. Charging trucks (<capacity> kWh) start at a depot (<loc_depot>) but remain at their final stop to avoid empty return trips. The goal is to minimize total travel distance while ensuring no truck exceeds its energy capacity and all vehicles are charged within their operational time slots.

title: Just-in-Time Aircraft Catering Delivery
content: An airline catering company must deliver pre-ordered meals (<demand> kg) to multiple aircraft at an airport (<loc_customer>) during strict turnaround times (<time_windows>). Delivery trucks (<capacity> kg) depart from a central kitchen (<loc_depot>) but stay airside after final delivery. Routes must account for tarmac speed limits (<speed>), unloading times (<service_time>), and perishable meal constraints without overloading trucks. The objective is to minimize total tarmac congestion while meeting all flight schedules.

title: Pop-Up COVID-19 Booster Shot Clinics
content: A health department organizes mobile vaccination teams to visit temporary clinics (<loc_customer>) with daily appointment slots (<time_windows>). Each clinic requires a specific vaccine quantity (<demand> doses), and refrigerated vans (<capacity> doses) depart from a central storage facility (<loc_depot>). Teams conclude operations at their last site without returning. The challenge is to optimize routes that respect cold-chain capacity limits and ensure no clinic misses its allocated time window due to late arrivals.

title: Luxury Watch Showroom Appointments
content: A high-end retailer schedules home demonstrations for VIP clients (<loc_customer>) during 1-hour appointment windows (<time_windows>). Sales reps carry sample kits (<demand> units) in secured vehicles (<capacity> units) from a flagship store (<loc_depot>). After the last appointment, reps park at secure locations near their final stop. Routes must ensure no vehicle exceeds its sample inventory while minimizing travel time between tightly scheduled appointments.

title: Temporary Urban Beehive Pollination Services
content: An agritech firm deploys mobile beehives to pollinate urban farms (<loc_customer>) during specific flowering periods (<time_windows> days). Each farm requires a certain hive capacity (<demand> colonies), transported via climate-controlled trucks (<capacity> colonies) from a central apiary (<loc_depot>). Trucks remain at the last farm for ongoing maintenance. The optimization must balance hive capacity limits with precise pollination timing across scattered micro-farms while minimizing road miles.

title: Mobile COVID-19 Booster Shot Clinics
content:
A public health agency operates mobile vaccination units that must visit multiple temporary clinics (<loc_customer>) from a central depot (<loc_depot>). Each clinic has:  
- A strict operating window (<time_windows>) due to staffing availability  
- A predicted demand (<demand>) for vaccine doses  
- A 15-minute setup/service time (<service_time>)  
Vans with cold storage (<capacity>) must deliver doses without exceeding capacity. After the final clinic, units park at their last location for overnight storage (open route). The goal is to maximize daily vaccinations while minimizing travel distance.

title: Just-in-Time Aircraft Catering Delivery
content:
An airport catering service must deliver meals from a central kitchen (<loc_depot>) to parked aircraft (<loc_customer>) before scheduled departures. Each aircraft has:  
- A precise loading window (<time_windows>) based on flight schedules  
- A specific meal count (<demand>)  
- A 20-minute loading time (<service_time>)  
Electric carts (<capacity>) must complete deliveries without overloading. Drivers finish shifts at their last aircraft (open route). The objective is to minimize late deliveries and total energy consumption.

title: Pop-Up Luxury Watch Showroom Appointments
content:
A luxury brand tours cities with high-value watches transported in armored vans (<capacity>) from a secure depot (<loc_depot>). Each pop-up location (<loc_customer>):  
- Operates only during mall hours (<time_windows>)  
- Requires exact inventory sets (<demand>)  
- Needs 30-minute security checks (<service_time>)  
After the final showroom, vans proceed to overnight storage (open route). The challenge is to coordinate deliveries across multiple cities while minimizing armored escort costs.

title: Temporary Urban Beehive Pollination Services
content:
An agricultural company deploys mobile beehives (<capacity>) from a rural depot (<loc_depot>) to urban farms (<loc_customer>) during specific pollination periods:  
- Orchards have 2-hour optimal pollination windows (<time_windows>)  
- Each requires 3-5 hives (<demand>)  
- Takes 45 minutes to install (<service_time>)  
Trucks remain at the final farm for hive monitoring (open route). The goal is to maximize pollination coverage while minimizing bee stress from transit time.

title: Olympic Venue Medical Kit Restocking
content:
During the Olympics, a logistics team must replenish first-aid kits from a central warehouse (<loc_depot>) to competition venues (<loc_customer>):  
- Venues have narrow restocking windows (<time_windows>) between events  
- Demand varies by venue size (<demand>)  
- Requires 10-minute inventory checks (<service_time>)  
Electric utility vehicles (<capacity>) stay at their last venue for rapid response (open route). The objective is to prevent stockouts while avoiding interference with athletic events.

title: Mobile Library Book Rotation for Rural Schools
content: A county library system operates a mobile service that delivers books to remote schools (<loc_customer>) from a central distribution center (<loc_depot>). Each school has a specific demand (<demand>) for book rotations and must be visited during their operating hours (<time_windows>). The bookmobile has a limited capacity (<capacity>) and does not return to the depot after the last delivery, instead parking overnight at the final school. The goal is to minimize total travel distance while ensuring no school is missed and time windows are respected.

title: On-Demand Medical Sample Collection for Homebound Patients
content: A healthcare provider offers at-home blood sample collection for elderly patients across a metropolitan area. Nurses depart from a central lab (<loc_depot>) with cooled sample kits (<capacity> limit per vehicle). Each patient (<loc_customer>) has a strict time window (<time_windows>) for collection due to fasting requirements and clinic processing deadlines. After completing their route, nurses proceed directly to the testing facility rather than returning to the depot. The challenge is to optimize routes that respect both sample freshness (time windows) and vehicle capacity constraints.

title: Pop-Up Urban Farm Produce Distribution
content: An urban farming collective supplies fresh produce to neighborhood pickup points (<loc_customer>) from a central greenhouse (<loc_depot>). Each location has a unique demand (<demand>) and specific time windows (<time_windows>) when volunteers are available to receive deliveries. Electric cargo bikes (<capacity>) make deliveries and remain at the final stop for local promotions. The system requires routes that maximize produce freshness by minimizing transit time while adhering to both capacity and temporal constraints.

title: Temporary Wildlife Camera Maintenance in National Parks
content: Park rangers must service motion-activated cameras (<loc_customer>) scattered across a protected area. Starting from a ranger station (<loc_depot>), each vehicle carries replacement batteries and memory cards (<capacity>). Cameras have maintenance time windows (<time_windows>) aligned with animal activity patterns to minimize disturbance. Rangers finish routes at the farthest camera to conduct field observations. The solution must optimize routes that service all cameras within their ecological time windows without exceeding vehicle supply limits.

title: Mobile Voting Unit Deployment for Local Elections
content: A government agency dispatches voting vans (<capacity> ballots/equipment per vehicle) from an election office (<loc_depot>) to temporary polling sites (<loc_customer>). Each site has strict operating hours (<time_windows>) based on community availability. Vehicles remain at their final location to become stationary polling stations after the route. The routing must ensure all sites receive sufficient materials within their designated time frames while accounting for vehicle capacity constraints and one-way travel.

content: A service provider operates mobile charging units to replenish electric ride-sharing vehicles across a city. Each ride-sharing car (<loc_customer>) has a specific charging window (<time_windows>) based on driver availability and must receive a fixed energy amount (<demand> kWh). Charging trucks (<capacity> kWh) depart from a central hub (<loc_depot>) and do not return after their last charge. The goal is to minimize total distance while ensuring no truck exceeds capacity and all vehicles are serviced within their designated time slots.

Vehicles (capacity `<capacity>`) carry doses and staff but do not return to the depot after the final clinic. The goal is to minimize travel distance while ensuring no clinic runs out of doses or misses its time window.
